flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
This guide will unmake a Canon printer/scanner/fax into Maker resources. We are mainly going for the motors but so much more will come out of this eWaste. The principles and techniques here apply to unmaking most fabricated electronics ... a Phillips screwdriver is about as complicated a tool as you will need ... and something to pry with! Remember that most products are made by robotics or unskilled labor that needs to be able to snap and assemble pieces onto a moving stream of work in progress ... nothing fancy is involved in the assemblage once 10,000 engineers figure out all the parts involved.

So let's disassemble someone else's product.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This guide will unmake a Canon printer/scanner/fax into Maker resources. We are mainly going for the motors but so much more will come out of this eWaste. The principles and techniques here apply to unmaking most fabricated electronics ... a Phillips screwdriver is about as complicated a tool as you will need ... and something to pry with! Remember that most products are made by robotics or unskilled labor that needs to be able to snap and assemble pieces onto a moving stream of work in progress ... nothing fancy is involved in the assemblage once 10,000 engineers figure out all the parts involved.

So let's disassemble someone else's product.

Tools
  • #0 or #00 Philips Screwdriver
  • Small Flathead Screwdriver
  • Wire cutter/stripper
  • parts bin

lines.text: This is a multi-function machine so we will have a printer, a scanner (copier & fax), and miscellaneous paper trays and feeds. Should be lots of parts.
lines.text_raw: This is a multi-function machine so we will have a printer, a scanner (copier & fax), and miscellaneous paper trays and feeds. Should be lots of parts.

lines.text: Take apart the machine in chunks that are managable and make sense (printer, scanner, paper tray, etc.). Work on each section before breaking down the next. Try to keep things separated in trays as you work instead of lumping them into a pile.
lines.text_raw: Take apart the machine in chunks that are managable and make sense (printer, scanner, paper tray, etc.). Work on each section before breaking down the next. Try to keep things separated in trays as you work instead of lumping them into a pile.

lines.text: Get rid of the messy stuff! If the eWaste still has toner or ink cartridges bag them up and dispose of them at a recycling center (or mail them to one). Any other messy bits need to be cleaned before tearing down.
lines.text_raw: Get rid of the messy stuff! If the eWaste still has toner or ink cartridges bag them up and dispose of them at a recycling center (or mail them to one). Any other messy bits need to be cleaned before tearing down.

lines.text: Look for screws and tab connections. The basic idea is to remove any screws you can find - see if parts come off - if not, look for things to pry off.
lines.text_raw: Look for screws and tab connections. The basic idea is to remove any screws you can find - see if parts come off - if not, look for things to pry off.

lines.text: Let's start by removing the top lid of this puppy. It has nice square hinges that just slide up out of the bottom assembly. You will have to cut the wires on one hinge to free the top.
lines.text_raw: Let's start by removing the top lid of this puppy. It has nice square hinges that just slide up out of the bottom assembly. You will have to cut the wires on one hinge to free the top.

lines.text: Investigate the paper tray for any obvious screws, etc. to take off. Open flaps and remove from main body. Stash the plastic in the "salvaged plastic" bin for later.
lines.text_raw: Investigate the paper tray for any obvious screws, etc. to take off. Open flaps and remove from main body. Stash the plastic in the "salvaged plastic" bin for later.

lines.text: Aha!!!! Once the flaps are open the glisten of gold - or aluminum screws in our case - appears before our eyes. Get out the screwdriver and take 'em all out.
lines.text_raw: Aha!!!! Once the flaps are open the glisten of gold - or aluminum screws in our case - appears before our eyes. Get out the screwdriver and take 'em all out.

lines.text: Okay ... so we removed the screws and got this neat paper feed mechanism out. It has gears and rubber gripping rollers attached to a nice stainless steel rod assembly.
lines.text_raw: Okay ... so we removed the screws and got this neat paper feed mechanism out. It has gears and rubber gripping rollers attached to a nice stainless steel rod assembly.

lines.text: Let's leave it alone until later ... should try to use the entire assembly in future projects 'cause it is so cool.
lines.text_raw: Let's leave it alone until later ... should try to use the entire assembly in future projects 'cause it is so cool.

steps.title: Paper Tray: Flip over and remove screws.

lines.text: Nothing major here - easily-visible screws to remove. The white foam piece peels off and can be used as flexible white board or foam liner for tray or ???
lines.text_raw: Nothing major here - easily-visible screws to remove. The white foam piece peels off and can be used as flexible white board or foam liner for tray or ???

lines.text: The hinges have a great feel to them as if they were hydraulic. Hold on to these for a project - they will be great!
lines.text_raw: The hinges have a great feel to them as if they were hydraulic. Hold on to these for a project - they will be great!

lines.text: Now that the screws are out we try to separate the tray into smaller bits - but we can't .... it's "stuck." What we have here, children, are hidden tabs and snap points that hold this puppy together. Time to get out the trusty flathead screwdriver or mom's best dinner knives (maybe not) and start poking and prying the plastic seams apart.
lines.text_raw: Now that the screws are out we try to separate the tray into smaller bits - but we can't .... it's "stuck." What we have here, children, are hidden tabs and snap points that hold this puppy together. Time to get out the trusty flathead screwdriver or mom's best dinner knives (maybe not) and start poking and prying the plastic seams apart.

lines.text: You might want to put on safety glasses if you tend to really pry things apart. If you can remain calm you should be able to pry them open with no war wounds.
lines.text_raw: You might want to put on safety glasses if you tend to really pry things apart. If you can remain calm you should be able to pry them open with no war wounds.

lines.text: Now that we have pried open the tray we look for more screws - and find them! You know the drill ... take 'em out and store in the "salvaged screws" jar.
lines.text_raw: Now that we have pried open the tray we look for more screws - and find them! You know the drill ... take 'em out and store in the "salvaged screws" jar.

lines.text: Okay .... now we are in business. Now that the paper tray is a bit more exposed - you might say naked - we can see what treasures it offers.
lines.text_raw: Okay .... now we are in business. Now that the paper tray is a bit more exposed - you might say naked - we can see what treasures it offers.

lines.text: I see a motor ... not just a basic DC motor but a stepper motor (multiple wires). I actually expected this since a paper feed tray has to be able to grab the paper, feed it in 'til sensors tell it to stop, a little alignment, etc. That is the work of a stepper motor.
lines.text_raw: I see a motor ... not just a basic DC motor but a stepper motor (multiple wires). I actually expected this since a paper feed tray has to be able to grab the paper, feed it in 'til sensors tell it to stop, a little alignment, etc. That is the work of a stepper motor.

lines.text: See the screws? Remove the screws! But you might want to leave the motor attached to the metal bracket until you use them in a future project - you might use both motor and bracket together.
lines.text_raw: See the screws? Remove the screws! But you might want to leave the motor attached to the metal bracket until you use them in a future project - you might use both motor and bracket together.

lines.text: Let us not forget the little bits just 'cause we get some big bounty (motors) from this eWaste. All these screws and plastic rollers and springs will come into use and save you money.
lines.text_raw: Let us not forget the little bits just 'cause we get some big bounty (motors) from this eWaste. All these screws and plastic rollers and springs will come into use and save you money.

lines.text: If we gently pry out this roller with a small flat screwdriver we will end up with a roller, two springs, and a stainless steel rod - not bad for free.
lines.text_raw: If we gently pry out this roller with a small flat screwdriver we will end up with a roller, two springs, and a stainless steel rod - not bad for free.

lines.text: Paper Tray: Gears Galore!
lines.text_raw: Paper Tray: Gears Galore!

lines.text: There be gears in them there hills!! Okay, maybe not hundreds but enough to keep and use later. I've never met a bad gear ... even the plastic ones have hope of reuse.
lines.text_raw: There be gears in them there hills!! Okay, maybe not hundreds but enough to keep and use later. I've never met a bad gear ... even the plastic ones have hope of reuse.

lines.text: What have we learned about screws? You know the routine - show those screws who really wields the screwdriver in your house - let them mingle with their fellow friends in the salvage jar.
lines.text_raw: What have we learned about screws? You know the routine - show those screws who really wields the screwdriver in your house - let them mingle with their fellow friends in the salvage jar.

lines.text: See that funny gear with the tab sticking out of it? The tab near the notch? The tab that can be moved away from the notch? That is the tab that you move when you want to remove the SS (stainless steel) rod that is attached to the gear... the gear with the tab... the tab near the notch...
lines.text_raw: See that funny gear with the tab sticking out of it? The tab near the notch? The tab that can be moved away from the notch? That is the tab that you move when you want to remove the SS (stainless steel) rod that is attached to the gear... the gear with the tab... the tab near the notch...

lines.text: Okay - Pop Quiz Time. Remember the gear in the last step? The gear with the tab? The tab next to the notch? The tab that moves to release the SS rod from its mounting point? Well this is the backside of that gear ... that gear with the tab ... the tab near the notch that it moves away from.
lines.text_raw: Okay - Pop Quiz Time. Remember the gear in the last step? The gear with the tab? The tab next to the notch? The tab that moves to release the SS rod from its mounting point? Well this is the backside of that gear ... that gear with the tab ... the tab near the notch that it moves away from.

lines.text: Now we see the SS rod removed from its mounting point all because of a gear ... a gear with a tab ... a tab - oh, forget it.
lines.text_raw: Now we see the SS rod removed from its mounting point all because of a gear ... a gear with a tab ... a tab - oh, forget it.

lines.text: Do I need to repeat myself? See previous step lest I unleash more prose on you.
lines.text_raw: Do I need to repeat myself? See previous step lest I unleash more prose on you.

steps.title: Paper Tray: More Gears with Tabs!

lines.text: Look closely and we can see the tab that prevents the gear from coming off the SS rod. Using a small flat screwdriver we will pry that tab back while pressing the gear off the rod.
lines.text_raw: Look closely and we can see the tab that prevents the gear from coming off the SS rod. Using a small flat screwdriver we will pry that tab back while pressing the gear off the rod.

lines.text: Slides right off!
lines.text_raw: Slides right off!

steps.title: Paper Tray: More Tabs, No Gears!

lines.text: Another example of tabbed connectors that secure rods in place. This one has no gear attached. Just poke tab out of slot to release.
lines.text_raw: Another example of tabbed connectors that secure rods in place. This one has no gear attached. Just poke tab out of slot to release.

lines.text: Now we can see what the motor and gears and rods were all there for ... to feed paper from up top to underneath. Here are the electronics that it used. These are paper-out sensors and top-of-page sensors. Keep them for future use.
lines.text_raw: Now we can see what the motor and gears and rods were all there for ... to feed paper from up top to underneath. Here are the electronics that it used. These are paper-out sensors and top-of-page sensors. Keep them for future use.

lines.text: See any screws - take 'em out. See any tabs - un-tab 'em. Remove anything removable. Continue at your own pace.
lines.text_raw: See any screws - take 'em out. See any tabs - un-tab 'em. Remove anything removable. Continue at your own pace.

lines.text: Okay - we have gutted the left side for all its bits - now let's gut the right side for its stuff.
lines.text_raw: Okay - we have gutted the left side for all its bits - now let's gut the right side for its stuff.

lines.text: Okay - remove screw - pry out springs, etc. and we can say that the paper feed tray is salvaged for all its parts. You did get the little paper-out lever and white roller thingy - right?
lines.text_raw: Okay - remove screw - pry out springs, etc. and we can say that the paper feed tray is salvaged for all its parts. You did get the little paper-out lever and white roller thingy - right?

lines.text: Paper Tray: The Booty Call!
lines.text_raw: Paper Tray: The Booty Call!

lines.text: Here are some of the major pieces off the paper feed tray. Cherish and fondle 'cause they are yours and free for the dismantling
lines.text_raw: Here are some of the major pieces off the paper feed tray. Cherish and fondle 'cause they are yours and free for the dismantling

lines.text: Take a break - get some water - clear your head and walk around. Why, you ask? Because we are about to delve into more dismantling of this Canon and we don't want you to pass out on us - so get refueled and report back for duty ASAP!
lines.text_raw: Take a break - get some water - clear your head and walk around. Why, you ask? Because we are about to delve into more dismantling of this Canon and we don't want you to pass out on us - so get refueled and report back for duty ASAP!

lines.text: Back to the main carcass we resume the usual routine of looking for screws and tabs to remove. Obvious ones near the square hinge holder get removed first.
lines.text_raw: Back to the main carcass we resume the usual routine of looking for screws and tabs to remove. Obvious ones near the square hinge holder get removed first.

lines.text: While looking for screws to remove on the back panel ... you see them? ... it looks like the power cord plugged in here. Let's check it out.
lines.text_raw: While looking for screws to remove on the back panel ... you see them? ... it looks like the power cord plugged in here. Let's check it out.

lines.text: Flip the whole thing over and we see a power supply unit nestled into the bottom. Input is 120Vac ... Output is 24Vdc
lines.text_raw: Flip the whole thing over and we see a power supply unit nestled into the bottom. Input is 120Vac ... Output is 24Vdc

lines.text: Look closely to see what is needed to remove it.
lines.text_raw: Look closely to see what is needed to remove it.

lines.text: So a tab holds in this power supply. Use a small screwdriver to pry it back while lifting out the unit.
lines.text_raw: So a tab holds in this power supply. Use a small screwdriver to pry it back while lifting out the unit.

lines.text: Power Supply: Remove and Unplug.
lines.text_raw: Power Supply: Remove and Unplug.

lines.text: Disconnect the ribbon cable.
lines.text_raw: Disconnect the ribbon cable.

lines.text: The rest of the wires will be molex-type connectors that can be pulled off.
lines.text_raw: The rest of the wires will be molex-type connectors that can be pulled off.

lines.text: Remove the screws and pull out the circuit board. You have some choices here: recycle the PCB properly, use it to make a nifty PCB clock, or embed it in your next terrazzo floor or cast-concrete countertop!
lines.text_raw: Remove the screws and pull out the circuit board. You have some choices here: recycle the PCB properly, use it to make a nifty PCB clock, or embed it in your next terrazzo floor or cast-concrete countertop!

lines.text: Capacitors are cheap, but consider salvaging them anyway because free is the best kind of cheap.
lines.text_raw: Capacitors are cheap, but consider salvaging them anyway because free is the best kind of cheap.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: The underside of the scanner has a couple of pieces you should get. Flip over and remove lever that holds up lid and spring related to it.
lines.text_raw: The underside of the scanner has a couple of pieces you should get. Flip over and remove lever that holds up lid and spring related to it.

lines.text: Remove plastic cover from button assembly by prying under edges with a small screwdriver. It was snapped on so removal is fairly quick. Unsnap it.
lines.text_raw: Remove plastic cover from button assembly by prying under edges with a small screwdriver. It was snapped on so removal is fairly quick. Unsnap it.

lines.text: Scanner: Remove Button Assembly.
lines.text_raw: Scanner: Remove Button Assembly.

lines.text: With the cover off we see screws we need to remove. Once those are out you can take out the button assembly.
lines.text_raw: With the cover off we see screws we need to remove. Once those are out you can take out the button assembly.

lines.text: A ribbon cable is attached but it pulls out easily.
lines.text_raw: A ribbon cable is attached but it pulls out easily.

lines.text: Flip over the assembly .... guess what we do with the screws? NOTHING YET ... I am saving the tear-down of this for later ... but you can remove screws if you must.
lines.text_raw: Flip over the assembly .... guess what we do with the screws? NOTHING YET ... I am saving the tear-down of this for later ... but you can remove screws if you must.

lines.text: Okay - Back to the printer carcass. Look for all visible screws and remove them, but most of those are probably hidden behind snapped-on plastic panels. Let's pry off those panels ... no need to be gentle.
lines.text_raw: Okay - Back to the printer carcass. Look for all visible screws and remove them, but most of those are probably hidden behind snapped-on plastic panels. Let's pry off those panels ... no need to be gentle.

lines.text: There are tabs that need to be pried open. Luckily they are not so hidden and marked with an arrow (not an X) ... you can see them in the pics of the side panels removed ... go ahead and pry them open.
lines.text_raw: There are tabs that need to be pried open. Luckily they are not so hidden and marked with an arrow (not an X) ... you can see them in the pics of the side panels removed ... go ahead and pry them open.

lines.text: Almost ready to shed the plastic shell ... a couple of things holding it together ... so on with another step.
lines.text_raw: Almost ready to shed the plastic shell ... a couple of things holding it together ... so on with another step.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Before you throw away the plastic printer shell you need to check for precious bits.
lines.text_raw: Before you throw away the plastic printer shell you need to check for precious bits.

lines.text: See that square hole in the shell ... down in the lower left of pic? Flip the shell over and look at that spot ... what do you see?
lines.text_raw: See that square hole in the shell ... down in the lower left of pic? Flip the shell over and look at that spot ... what do you see?

lines.text: Paper-out switch!!!! yea .... applause ... this little switch will be gold when you need to add obstacle detectors on a moving robot. Keep this puppy handy.
lines.text_raw: Paper-out switch!!!! yea .... applause ... this little switch will be gold when you need to add obstacle detectors on a moving robot. Keep this puppy handy.

lines.text: When we took a panel off one side of the printer we spied this gear assembly. Gears good ... gears make me drool ... gears good.
lines.text_raw: When we took a panel off one side of the printer we spied this gear assembly. Gears good ... gears make me drool ... gears good.

lines.text: Take the screws out (you knew that - didn't you?) that attach the gear mechanism to the printer body. Remove the mechanism.
lines.text_raw: Take the screws out (you knew that - didn't you?) that attach the gear mechanism to the printer body. Remove the mechanism.

lines.text: You can leave it as is for later or go ahead and dissect the mechanism for the indy gears and bits. Fondle at will.
lines.text_raw: You can leave it as is for later or go ahead and dissect the mechanism for the indy gears and bits. Fondle at will.

lines.text: Bag & Tag! Keep the mechanism and parts together ... yoiu may want to use the entire assembly later.
lines.text_raw: Bag & Tag! Keep the mechanism and parts together ... yoiu may want to use the entire assembly later.

lines.text: Back to the printer body remains. Take a look at the goodies ... more motors ... more gears ... more electronics.
lines.text_raw: Back to the printer body remains. Take a look at the goodies ... more motors ... more gears ... more electronics.

lines.text: Motors!!! I actually see two down there ... expected to see two since a printer needs a motor for the ink cartridge axis that moves the printheads and a motor to move and align the paper.
lines.text_raw: Motors!!! I actually see two down there ... expected to see two since a printer needs a motor for the ink cartridge axis that moves the printheads and a motor to move and align the paper.

lines.text: Sometimes things are not so easy. Here we have lovely gears to get to but they are in the proximity of the whole ink pump / head cleaning station that holds nothing but a mess. Old ink and tubes with crud, etc. So tread lightly through this inky quagmire.
lines.text_raw: Sometimes things are not so easy. Here we have lovely gears to get to but they are in the proximity of the whole ink pump / head cleaning station that holds nothing but a mess. Old ink and tubes with crud, etc. So tread lightly through this inky quagmire.

lines.text: Electronics!! I think we already removed a USB cable / plug-in port thingy earlier - right? Well, let's not forget the phone plug jacks (with nifty plastic plug for non-used port).
lines.text_raw: Electronics!! I think we already removed a USB cable / plug-in port thingy earlier - right? Well, let's not forget the phone plug jacks (with nifty plastic plug for non-used port).

lines.text: Circuit board goes. Remove as many wires off the board as possible.
lines.text_raw: Circuit board goes. Remove as many wires off the board as possible.

lines.text: What stands in your way of getting these items? Screws! You know the drill - just don't use one 'cause a screwdriver will work better.
lines.text_raw: What stands in your way of getting these items? Screws! You know the drill - just don't use one 'cause a screwdriver will work better.

lines.text: Don't forget to look for sensors, etc. that are housed on their own little circuit board. They often hang out near the ends of paper rollers and axles so they can monitor rotation and such.
lines.text_raw: Don't forget to look for sensors, etc. that are housed on their own little circuit board. They often hang out near the ends of paper rollers and axles so they can monitor rotation and such.

lines.text: Time to take the speaker out. Unwrap and remove any wires that you can.
lines.text_raw: Time to take the speaker out. Unwrap and remove any wires that you can.

lines.text: Pull back white tab to remove speaker from white housing (keep).
lines.text_raw: Pull back white tab to remove speaker from white housing (keep).

lines.text: Remove housing by removing screws. Put speaker back in housing once removed ... store together since made for each other.
lines.text_raw: Remove housing by removing screws. Put speaker back in housing once removed ... store together since made for each other.

lines.text: Scrounge around for springs and rollers and pins and rods that are quickly removed.
lines.text_raw: Scrounge around for springs and rollers and pins and rods that are quickly removed.

lines.text: Removing screws should yield this ink cartridge guide structure.
lines.text_raw: Removing screws should yield this ink cartridge guide structure.

lines.text: Set aside for later destruction.
lines.text_raw: Set aside for later destruction.

lines.text: The stainless steel (SS) roller bars are held in with tabs that unlock the rod if you release the tab from its notch and rotate so that it can slide out of the printer body.
lines.text_raw: The stainless steel (SS) roller bars are held in with tabs that unlock the rod if you release the tab from its notch and rotate so that it can slide out of the printer body.

lines.text: Try to find and unlatch as many roller bars as possible.
lines.text_raw: Try to find and unlatch as many roller bars as possible.

lines.text: This is messy so take your time. Once you remove the rollers you should have access to the gear cluster and ink pump thingy. Remove and bag it.
lines.text_raw: This is messy so take your time. Once you remove the rollers you should have access to the gear cluster and ink pump thingy. Remove and bag it.

lines.text: Foam pads have soaked up some ink so if you remove and toss it should be easier to handle.
lines.text_raw: Foam pads have soaked up some ink so if you remove and toss it should be easier to handle.

lines.text: All that remains in the printer body is a miscellaneous lever that can be removed if you line up the tabs.
lines.text_raw: All that remains in the printer body is a miscellaneous lever that can be removed if you line up the tabs.

lines.text: The printer carcass is stripped down and ready to recycle. Take care to dispose of those ink pads carefully.
lines.text_raw: The printer carcass is stripped down and ready to recycle. Take care to dispose of those ink pads carefully.

lines.text: If any ink pads have stayed clean you can use them for blotting up things. I use them in my soldering station to wipe the soldering iron tip on to keep it clean.
lines.text_raw: If any ink pads have stayed clean you can use them for blotting up things. I use them in my soldering station to wipe the soldering iron tip on to keep it clean.

lines.text: Printer: More Little Bits!
lines.text_raw: Printer: More Little Bits!

lines.text: Look at the miscellaneous paper trays and drawers that came with this printer. If you see any buttons or springs or whatever .... pry apart to get to the innards and remove the goods.
lines.text_raw: Look at the miscellaneous paper trays and drawers that came with this printer. If you see any buttons or springs or whatever .... pry apart to get to the innards and remove the goods.

lines.text: edit this out ..
lines.text_raw: edit this out ..

lines.text: Okay - time to get back to the teardown of the scanner.
lines.text_raw: Okay - time to get back to the teardown of the scanner.

lines.text: The usual culprits are keeping this together .... screws & tabs ... you know what to do ....
lines.text_raw: The usual culprits are keeping this together .... screws & tabs ... you know what to do ....

lines.text: Once tabs are removed you can peel off the plastic layer with the scanner glass in it.
lines.text_raw: Once tabs are removed you can peel off the plastic layer with the scanner glass in it.

lines.text: If you want to remove the glass from the plastric you need to remove the white tab with the "F" on it.
lines.text_raw: If you want to remove the glass from the plastric you need to remove the white tab with the "F" on it.

lines.text: I chose to leave the glass & plastic together for now. It might become part of a light box or tracing table.
lines.text_raw: I chose to leave the glass & plastic together for now. It might become part of a light box or tracing table.

lines.text: You see the motor? That is a stepper motor and makes this whole teardown worth it. That baby is gold!
lines.text_raw: You see the motor? That is a stepper motor and makes this whole teardown worth it. That baby is gold!

lines.text: The scanner unit travels back and forth, to and fro, here and there along a small rail system they built into the plastic housing. This is cheap and the scanner head lifts out easily. So do most of the wires and hardware in this unit. Tale out what you can.
lines.text_raw: The scanner unit travels back and forth, to and fro, here and there along a small rail system they built into the plastic housing. This is cheap and the scanner head lifts out easily. So do most of the wires and hardware in this unit. Tale out what you can.

lines.text: Now take a screwdriver out and get to the motor. Try to remove the whole unit and leave intact for now.
lines.text_raw: Now take a screwdriver out and get to the motor. Try to remove the whole unit and leave intact for now.

lines.text: Here it is ... a beautiful stepper motor ... with info on the back. When I google that I find what? (Google and post results.)
lines.text_raw: Here it is ... a beautiful stepper motor ... with info on the back. When I google that I find what? (Google and post results.)

lines.text: All that is left is to tear apart the button assembly ... another step for that ... for now - gather up the scanner bits and put all together for a photo op.
lines.text_raw: All that is left is to tear apart the button assembly ... another step for that ... for now - gather up the scanner bits and put all together for a photo op.

lines.text: The scan head unit has some tabs to pry apart in order to get to its innards. Pry open and remove small bits.
lines.text_raw: The scan head unit has some tabs to pry apart in order to get to its innards. Pry open and remove small bits.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: See what nice parts that generated?
lines.text_raw: See what nice parts that generated?

lines.text: You can remove the buttons or use it to build a game with an Arduino.
lines.text_raw: You can remove the buttons or use it to build a game with an Arduino.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

lines.text: Insert wisdom here.
lines.text_raw: Insert wisdom here.

steps.title: Ink Cartridge Chassis: Tear it Down

lines.text: Usually I leave these things intact until I know what I want to do with them. Often they are best kept as a unit 'cause you can get rid of the ink cartridge and replace it with something else to be controlled on an X-axis with the motor.
lines.text_raw: Usually I leave these things intact until I know what I want to do with them. Often they are best kept as a unit 'cause you can get rid of the ink cartridge and replace it with something else to be controlled on an X-axis with the motor.

lines.text: Yes .... a motor ... the real treasure in this unit.
lines.text_raw: Yes .... a motor ... the real treasure in this unit.

lines.text: Often a little plastic strip is attached to a small tab ... it pulls off easily.
lines.text_raw: Often a little plastic strip is attached to a small tab ... it pulls off easily.

steps.title: Ink Cartridge Chassis: Remove Screws & Tabs

lines.text: You thought you were done with the screwdriver? Ha! Back to the routine of finding screws to remove and tabs to turn or snap off.
lines.text_raw: You thought you were done with the screwdriver? Ha! Back to the routine of finding screws to remove and tabs to turn or snap off.

lines.text: Aside from the aforementioned plastic strip there are roller pulleys and springs to harvest in this piece.
lines.text_raw: Aside from the aforementioned plastic strip there are roller pulleys and springs to harvest in this piece.

lines.text: Ink Cartridge Chassis: Booty Haul!
lines.text_raw: Ink Cartridge Chassis: Booty Haul!

lines.text: We've got a motor, ribbed drive belt, rollers and hardware, plus the metal chassis itself to recycle for cash. Not a bad haul for a small unit.
lines.text_raw: We've got a motor, ribbed drive belt, rollers and hardware, plus the metal chassis itself to recycle for cash. Not a bad haul for a small unit.

lines.text: The motor in this unit is a ????? (will look up specs online & post).
lines.text_raw: The motor in this unit is a ????? (will look up specs online & post).

lines.text: The ink cartridge housing has a couple of tabs that need to be pried open and a screw here or there. Look around and remove.
lines.text_raw: The ink cartridge housing has a couple of tabs that need to be pried open and a screw here or there. Look around and remove.

lines.text: See what that generated ... not bad for nothin'.
lines.text_raw: See what that generated ... not bad for nothin'.

lines.text: What a haul ... 4 fine motors and several SS roller bars.
lines.text_raw: What a haul ... 4 fine motors and several SS roller bars.

lines.text: Sort and collect the plastic into boxes / bins. After a few unMakings of eWaste you will have enough scrap to take to a recycle center, if they take plastic, or an eWaste event drop-off.
lines.text_raw: Sort and collect the plastic into boxes / bins. After a few unMakings of eWaste you will have enough scrap to take to a recycle center, if they take plastic, or an eWaste event drop-off.

lines.text: Save the metal bits and when you have a boxful you can take it to the cash-for-metal recycling center. Try to sort by type: stainless steel, aluminum, basic steel, etc.
lines.text_raw: Save the metal bits and when you have a boxful you can take it to the cash-for-metal recycling center. Try to sort by type: stainless steel, aluminum, basic steel, etc.

guide.summary: Before you make something it is helpful to unmake something. This guide will show you that eWaste should never be thrown away until you gut it for the good stuff. What good stuff, you ask? How about DC motors, stepper motors, power supplies, gears, etc.?
guide.title: Don't Waste eWaste: UnMaking a Canon Printer/Scanner/Fax into Parts
